SENT.plain: AIMS: To establish the prevalence of atrial fibrillation (AF) in the general population in the UK, and in those with risk factors

METHODS AND RESULTS: The prevalence of AF on electrocardiography was established in prospectively selected groups: 3960 randomly selected from the population, aged 45+; 782 with a previous diagnosis of heart failure; and 1062 with a record of myocardial infarction, hypertension, angina, or diabetes
Patients were also assessed clinically and with echocardiography
Atrial fibrillation was found in 78 of the random population sample (2.0%)
Prevalence was 1.6% in women and 2.4% in men, rising with age from 0.2% in those aged 45-54 to 8.0% in those aged 75 and older
Half of all cases were in patients aged 75 and older
Only 23 of the 78 (29.5%) of those in AF took warfarin
Of the 782 patients, 175 (22.4%) with a diagnosis of heart failure were in AF, with normal left ventricular function in 95 (54.3%) of these

Atrial fibrillation was found in 14 of the 244 (5.7%) of those with a history of myocardial infarction, 15 of the 388 (3.9%) of those with hypertension, 15 of the 321 (4.7%) of those with angina, and 11 of the 208 (5.3%) of diabetics
Adjusting for age and sex, mortality was 1.57 times higher for those in AF
CONCLUSION: Atrial fibrillation is common in the elderly and those with clinical risk factors
Screening these groups would identify many with AF
Use of anticoagulation was low at the time of the initial assessments in the late 1990s; practice may have changed recently
